question: 1. You are given pointers to first and last nodes of a singly linked list, which of the following operations are dependent on the length of the linked list?

answers.b: Insert a new element as a first element
answers.c: Delete the last element of the list
answers.d: Add a new element at the end of the list

question: 2. Which of the following points is/ are true about Linked List data structure when it is compared?

answers.a: Arrays have better cache locality that can make them better in terms of performance
answers.b: It is easy to insert and delete elements in Linked List
answers.c: Random access is not allowed in a typical implementation of Linked Lists

question: 3. Pick one correct statement from the following?

answers.a: In doubly linked list, each node is linked to one node.
answers.b: In doubly linked list, each node is linked to three nodes.
answers.c: In doubly linked list, each node is linked to two nodes.
answers.d: In doubly linked list, each node is linked to zero nodes.

question: 4.  Is it possible to create a doubly linked list using only one pointer with every node?

answers.b: Yes, possible by storing XOR of addresses of previous and next nodes.
answers.c: Yes, possible by storing XOR of addresses of current node and next node
answers.d: Yes, possible by storing XOR of addresses of current node and previous node

question: 5. What differentiates a circular linked list from a normal linked list?

answers.a: You cannot have the ‘next’ pointer point to null in a circular linked list
answers.b: It is faster to traverse the circular linked list
answers.c: You may or may not have the ‘next’ pointer point to null in a circular linked list

question: 6. What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a circular linked list?
7. Which of the following is false about a circular linked list?

answers.b: Time complexity of inserting a new node at the head of the list is O(1)
answers.c: Time complexity for deleting the last node is O(n)

question: 8. A circularly linked list is used to represent a Queue. A single variable p is used to access the Queue. To which node should p point such that both the operations enQueue and deQueue can be performed in constant time?

answers.c: not possible with a single pointer
